OSGi and Jigsaw both just need a unique module ID. For OSGi it's called export-package, for JigSaw, I guess module ID.
Other additional features of OSGi, such as osgi-specific code for dynamic loading is not in our scope.

nodes.bodyText: I don't much like regexes in Java, as they become very hard to read. Did you consider using \Q no need to escape in here \E to reduce some of that escaping?

What do you mean by \Q no need to escape in here \E? Though I do agree that these Java regexes are very ugly, see another example in optaplanner-persistence-jaxb. This PR actually is consistent with that style, though we might as well overhaul all of them in a separate PR. @ge0ffrey WDYT?
In a Java regex string, you can use \Q to start a sequence in which escaping is not necessary. \E ends that sequence.
I see, yes that would be a lot cleaner. In any case, we would have to change this for all the other modules, so I'm going to hide behind scope creep for this PR.

Suggestion: instead of using a regex, consider parsing the JSON again and make sure it has the structure you're expecting it to. This will make sure the JSON is valid, without you having to deal with the actual JSON syntax.

Similar to my comment above, this is currently the practice in the other optaplanner modules. The mentioned overhaul would address this, but I don't see this regex json check as a blocker for this specific PR (not in scope imo).
Abstract class without any methods? Looks like an interface to me. :-)
Also, as you're using it from a whole bunch of subclasses, I feel that it should be a top-level interface.
Normally I would agree with you, but this class is closely tied and used immediately in the same file. Also note that we see this practice here. This overhaul is looking more and more convincing.
Putting this abstract class in the same file helps with readability, but that's my opinion.
OK, I don't have a strong preference either way. Consistency wins.
Not sure why does this method have the score argument, when it also has the wrapper which can return the score?

The score arg is used as a reference to assert that the Wrapper is serialized, then deserialized to contain the same score result. This approach is also used in the other modules, but we could discuss changing them all in a future PR.
Suggestion: put a comment in the empty constructor, saying something like "Required by JSON-B." People won't have to spend time thinking why the unused constructor is there.
Some of the test classes don't have the blank lines in here. I don't mind if you want to keep them - but in that case, be consistent, please.
Removing them for consistency with other modules.

Our friend, the code style. :-) We don't align on columns.
Anyway... leave it as it is, let's wait for Radek to bring his unifying PR.

In light of your recent changes, I was wondering... could we get rid of the Test...ScoreWrappers, if we use the new OptaplannerJsonbConfig here, @cuijulian ?
Unless there's some technical hurdle I'm overlooking, this could remove a lot of code from this PR.

Any such changes must also be applied to the jacksons tests (and potentially jaxb and xstream), for consistency.


Not sure about reusing the OptaPlannerJsonbConfig here: on one hand the philosophy of HardSoftScoreJsonbAdapterTest etc is to test the adaptor (= binding) in isolation, as a unit test. On the other hand, we want everyone to use the OptaPlannerJsonbConfig. So I am fine either way, as long is 1) is adhered to, with a slight preference to status quo. For Julian's sake, if we do it, I suggest in a follow up PR?

This is currently consistent with the Jackson tests, any refactors will have to be done in a separate PR on all existing modules like Jackson, Jaxb, etc. As Geoffrey mentioned in his comment below, these individual Score Adapter tests are not quite a duplicate of the OptaPlannerJsonbConfig test. The latter tests that the Config object (which contains all the Score Adapters) actually works when used on a Wrapper with multiple Score types.

For moment, I got confused that this test duplicates HardSoftScoreJsonbAdapterTest, but it doesn't.
The jackson version of this has 2 Scores, including a "generic Score", something not supported by JSON-B (which is fine).
Suggestion: Add a BendableScore too in this test (so it has 2 scores). Also add a BendableScore in the jackson version of this test (so it has 3 scores).
This does give us some extra test code coverage, to prove that bendables also work without explicit annotations :)
Will do.
